explanation: MHD_connection_close_ itself does not form a direct or indirect recursion: its own body calls MHD_destroy_response, MHD_pool_destroy and MHD_connection_mark_closed_. The only call in that chain that might lead back into MHD_destroy_response (or MHD_connection_close_) is the user-supplied callback response->crfc invoked by MHD_destroy_response. Whether an indirect recursion cycle exists therefore depends on the implementation of that callback (i.e. user code). MISRA Rule 17.2 forbids functions calling themselves (directly or indirectly) in the analysed code base. The library code shown does not, by itself, create a recursive call cycle — a recursive cycle would only occur if client code supplies a callback that calls back into the library, in which case the overall program (library + callback) would violate 17.2. So agent A’s claim that MHD_connection_close_ (as written) violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is not correct: the code permits a user-created recursion at runtime, but it does not itself statically create a recursion cycle.
